deliberation: Checked for metaphorical uses of דָּבָר ('word'), personification of 'word', or idiomatic expressions. Here דָּבָר הָיָה אֶל־יִרְמְיָהוּ functions as a standard prophetic formula meaning 'a message came to Jeremiah'; it is conventional and not deployed as a conscious figure. No clear figurative language.

Considered 'gate of the house of YHWH' for metonymy and 'hear the word of YHWH' as idiom or metaphor for obedience. In this context the gate is the literal temple gate and 'hear the word' is a standard prophetic summons without further figurative exploitation. Overall the verse is structurally literal.

Looked for metaphors in 'mend your ways and your actions' and for any personification of the land or place. The key figurative element is the conventional biblical metaphor of 'way' (דֶּרֶךְ) for moral conduct.

instances.english_text: Mend your ways and your actions
target: The people's moral and religious behavior ('your ways and your actions')
vehicle: A physical road or path that can be improved or straightened
ground: Both behavior and a path can follow a wrong course and be corrected or made 'good'
instances.explanation: The verse uses the common Hebrew metaphor of 'way' (דֶּרֶךְ) to depict moral conduct as a path that can be improved or straightened.

deliberation: Considered whether 'trusting in deceptive words' is metaphorical (trust as physical support) and whether the triple 'Temple of YHWH' slogan functions ironically. The verse is primarily a literal warning against a specific false slogan; the repetition is rhetorical but not clearly a distinct metaphor, simile, or personification.

Again examined 'mend your ways and your actions' and the phrase 'execute justice' for figurative usage. As in v.3, 'ways' (דְּרָכִים) is a path metaphor for conduct; the rest is straightforward legal language.

instances.english_text: if you really mend your ways and your actions
vehicle: A road or way that can be improved or made straight
ground: Both behavior and a path can be on a wrong or right course and can be 'made good'
instances.explanation: The verse uses 'ways' as a metaphor for habitual behavior, portraying ethical reform as the repair of a path.

deliberation: Checked 'do not oppress the stranger, orphan, widow' (literal), 'do not shed innocent blood' and 'do not go after other gods' for figurative language. Found (1) a blood synecdoche/idiom for killing, and (2) another path metaphor in 'go after other gods.'

instances.english_text: do not shed the blood of the innocent
vehicle: Blood as a visible fluid that can be poured out
ground: Blood represents the life of the person so that 'shedding blood' equals killing
part standing for the whole person
instances.explanation: This is an idiomatic synecdoche: 'blood' stands for the whole person so that 'shedding blood' means killing the innocent.

instances.english_text: if you do not follow other gods
target: The people's religious allegiance and worship practices
vehicle: Walking behind someone on a path
ground: Both discipleship/worship and walking behind someone imply commitment and following their lead
instances.explanation: The idiom 'walk after other gods' uses journey imagery to depict religious allegiance as following a leader along a path.

deliberation: Considered whether 'dwell in this place' is metaphorical (it is literal) and examined 'from of old forever and ever' (לְמִן־עוֹלָם וְעַד־עוֹלָם) for hyperbolic extension of time. It functions as an exaggeration for perpetuity.

instances.english_text: for all time (from eternity to eternity)
target: Duration of Israel's dwelling in the land
vehicle: An unbounded stretch 'from eternity to eternity'
ground: The promise is depicted as extending indefinitely, like an unbounded span in both directions
instances.explanation: The phrase uses temporal hyperbole—'from eternity to eternity'—to stress the intended permanence of the land grant, not to define a literal infinite duration.

deliberation: Reviewed 'trusting in deceptive words that do not profit' for metaphor (trust as physical support, profit as commercial metaphor). These are conventional abstract uses in Hebrew and not strongly foregrounded as figures here. No clear, marked figurative expression beyond normal abstraction.

Most verbs (steal, murder, commit adultery, swear falsely) are literal. The final clause 'go after other gods' reprises the path metaphor of v.6, depicting idolatry as following. That is the distinct figurative expression here.

instances.hebrew_text: וְהָלֹךְ אַחֲרֵי אֱלֹהִים אֲחֵרִים אֲשֶׁר לֹא־יְדַעְתֶּם
instances.english_text: and follow other gods whom you have not experienced
target: The people’s choice to worship other deities
vehicle: Walking behind someone as a follower on a road
ground: Both discipleship/worship and physical following involve commitment to go where the leader goes
direction of one’s course by another
posture: Critical exposure of their misplaced loyalty
instances.explanation: The idiom 'go after other gods' uses journey imagery to picture worship as following a leader down a path.

deliberation: Considered (1) 'house that is called by My name' for metonymy of 'name' as presence/ownership, and (2) the claim 'We are safe in order to do all these abominations' as an ironic reversal of deliverance language. Both are distinct figures.

instances.english_text: this House that bears My name
target: The Jerusalem temple as locus of divine presence
vehicle: A 'name' placed upon a house to indicate ownership or association
ground: Having a name on a house signifies belonging and identification, so God's 'name' signifies His presence and claim over the temple
posture: Undermining false confidence in the building
instances.explanation: God’s 'name' functions metonymically for His presence and ownership; the temple is described as the house upon which His name is called.

instances.hebrew_text: וַאֲמַרְתֶּם נִצַּלְנוּ לְמַעַן עֲשׂוֹת אֵת כָּל־הַתּוֹעֵבוֹת הָאֵלֶּה
instances.english_text: and say, “We are safe”—[safe] to do all these abhorrent things!
target: The people’s self-deception about salvation and security
vehicle: Deliverance language typically used for God’s true rescue
ground: The claim to be 'delivered' is perversely used to justify sin, creating a sharp ironic contrast between true and false deliverance
instances.explanation: There is verbal irony: they invoke the language of deliverance ('we are saved') precisely to license the abominations that would warrant judgment.

deliberation: Identified (1) a temple metaphor as 'den of robbers,' and (2) repetition of the 'house that is called by My name' metonymy. Both are distinct: one re-images the temple, the other explains its divine association.

instances.english_text: Has this House become, in your eyes, a den of thieves?
target: The corrupt use of the temple by the people
their religious practice and gathering place
vehicle: A cave or den where violent robbers hide and feel secure
ground: Both a robbers’ den and the abused temple serve as a false refuge where wrongdoers feel safe from consequences
instances.explanation: The temple is likened to a robbers’ cave, suggesting it has become a safe hideout for criminals rather than a holy place.

instances.english_text: this House, which bears My name
target: The temple as site of divine presence
vehicle: A 'name' attached to a house indicating ownership and fame
ground: The divine name stands for God Himself, so a house 'called by His name' signifies His claimed presence there
posture: Reminder of the temple's true identity
instances.explanation: God’s 'name' functions metonymically for His person and reputation; calling the temple by His name expresses His claim over it.

deliberation: Looked at 'My place at Shiloh' and 'where I caused My name to dwell there at first.' The key figure is again the metonymic use of God's 'name' for His presence and ownership.

instances.english_text: where I had established My name formerly
target: The manifestation of God's presence at Shiloh
vehicle: Causing a 'name' to dwell in a place
name as stand-in for a person
ground: Having one’s name dwell somewhere indicates association and presence, so God's 'name' stands for His own dwelling there
instances.explanation: God’s 'name' is used metonymically for His personal presence; Shiloh was where His name—hence His presence—formerly resided.

deliberation: Considered the verbs 'spoke' and 'called'—literal for prophetic communication—and especially the idiom 'rising early and speaking' (הַשְׁכֵּם וְדַבֵּר) which anthropomorphically depicts God as an eager early riser. This is a personifying idiom stressing persistence.

instances.english_text: though I spoke to you persistently (rising early and speaking)
target: God’s repeated sending of messages through prophets
vehicle: A human who rises early in the morning to speak diligently
ground: Both an early riser and God’s prophetic activity show diligence and urgency in addressing others
posture: Emphasis on God’s earnest efforts vs. their stubbornness
instances.explanation: The idiom 'rising early and speaking' personifies God with a human daily routine to underline how diligently and repeatedly He has warned them.

deliberation: Examined the threat language. The notable figure is again 'the house that is called by My name'—metonymy for God’s presence at the temple. The comparison with Shiloh itself is historical, not metaphorical.

instances.hebrew_text: לַבַּיִת אֲשֶׁר נִקְרָא־שְׁמִי עָלָיו אֲשֶׁר אַתֶּם בֹּטְחִים בּוֹ
instances.english_text: to the House that bears My name, on which you rely
target: The physical temple as focal point of misplaced trust
vehicle: A house carrying an owner’s name
ground: The association of name and house signals ownership; God’s 'name' stands for Himself, so the phrase denotes His claimed presence there
presence and authority implied by label
instances.explanation: Again God’s 'name' functions metonymically for His person; the temple is described as the house called by that name.

deliberation: Considered 'cast you out from before My face' and 'seed of Ephraim.' 'Seed' for descendants is lexicalized, but 'from before My face' clearly uses 'face' as metonymy for presence, expressing relational expulsion.

instances.english_text: And I will cast you out of My presence (from before My face)
target: The people’s covenant relationship and access to God
vehicle: Being thrown away from in front of someone’s face
physical displacement from a ruler’s presence
ground: To be in front of someone’s face is to enjoy their presence; being cast away depicts total rejection
instances.explanation: God’s 'face' stands metonymically for His presence; being cast away from His face portrays loss of relationship in spatial terms.

deliberation: Checked whether 'I will not listen to you' is figurative beyond standard anthropomorphic language. Here 'listen' means 'heed/respond to' in a normal sense; the verse is a straightforward prohibition of intercession with no marked metaphor or simile.
Descriptive question about what they do in towns and streets. No metaphors, similes, or personifications detected; 'see' is literal cognition and locations are concrete.

Narrates literal cultic preparations for idolatry: gathering wood, kindling fire, kneading dough, making cakes, pouring libations. 'Queen of Heaven' is a cult title for a goddess, not a metaphor in this context. No clear figurative language.

Considered whether God's being 'vexed' is merely anthropomorphic (standard) and examined 'for the shame of their faces' (לְמַעַן בֹּשֶׁת פְּנֵיהֶם). Here 'faces' stand metonymically for their public self and honor, expressing disgrace.

instances.english_text: Is it not themselves, to their own disgrace (for the shame of their faces)?
target: The people’s public humiliation and loss of honor
vehicle: Faces experiencing shame or covered with shame
ground: The face represents the self before others; shame on the face expresses total public humiliation
outer countenance as sign of inner and social status
posture: Explanation of consequences of their sin
instances.explanation: ‘Faces’ function metonymically for their public self; the phrase depicts their idolatry as resulting in visible, public shame.

deliberation: Noted two main figures: (1) God’s anger and wrath 'poured out' and 'burning' unquenchably—a complex metaphor of wrath as consuming fire/liquid; (2) the list 'on human, on beast, on tree of the field, on fruit of the ground' functioning as a merism for total devastation of all life and produce.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּה אַפִּי וַחֲמָתִי נִתֶּכֶת אֶל־הַמָּקוֹם הַזֶּה ... וּבָעֲרָה וְלֹא תִכְבֶּה
instances.english_text: My wrath and My fury will be poured out upon this place … It shall burn, with none to quench it.
target: The destructive exercise of God’s judgment
vehicle: A burning, unquenchable substance (like molten metal or fire) being poured out and blazing
ground: Both unquenchable fire and divine wrath are intense, consuming, and unstoppable once unleashed
instances.explanation: Wrath is conceptualized as a poured-out, unquenchable blaze, using fire/liquid imagery to emphasize its consuming and unstoppable nature.

instances.hebrew_text: עַל־הָאָדָם וְעַל־הַבְּהֵמָה וְעַל־עֵץ הַשָּׂדֶה וְעַל־פְּרִי הָאֲדָמָה
instances.english_text: upon human beings and on animals, on the trees of the field and the fruit of the soil
target: All forms of life and productivity in the land
vehicle: A fourfold list of representative categories: humans, beasts, trees, fruits
ground: Listing main categories of life and produce suggests that nothing in the land will escape the judgment
parts used to imply the whole (merism)
instances.explanation: The list functions as a merism: representative elements (humans, animals, trees, crops) stand for the entire creation of the land that will be affected.

deliberation: The directive to 'add your burnt offerings to your sacrifices and eat the meat' runs counter to sacrificial law and is widely read as biting irony, not a literal instruction. It uses an ironic command to expose the worthlessness of their cult.

instances.english_text: Add your burnt offerings to your other sacrifices and eat the meat!
target: The people’s reliance on sacrificial ritual
vehicle: A sarcastic invitation to pile up offerings and treat them like ordinary meat
ground: By telling them to do more of what is actually rejected, the statement exposes that their sacrifices are no better than common food
instances.explanation: This is an ironic command: God mockingly tells them to combine burnt offerings with other sacrifices and eat, highlighting that He finds their cultic acts meaningless.

deliberation: The claim 'I did not speak…concerning burnt offerings or sacrifice' is rhetorically absolute though sacrificial laws do exist. It is hyperbolic contrast, stressing that sacrifice was not the primary demand compared to obedience.

instances.english_text: I did not speak with them or command them … concerning burnt offerings or sacrifice
target: The relative importance of sacrificial commands vs. obedience
vehicle: A categorical denial of having spoken about sacrifices
ground: The exaggerated denial serves to highlight that sacrifice was secondary compared to the central demand of obedience
posture: Corrective emphasis on obedience over ritual
instances.explanation: The verse employs hyperbolic negation: God says He did not command sacrifices, meaning they were not His primary concern compared to obeying His voice.

deliberation: Noted the covenant formula 'I will be your God, you will be My people' (largely literal covenant language) and 'walk in all the way that I command you,' which continues the 'way/path' metaphor for conduct.

instances.english_text: walk only in the way that I enjoin upon you
target: Their comprehensive pattern of living in obedience
ground: Obedient living is like following a prescribed path rather than wandering off it
instances.explanation: The 'way' is a metaphor for God's commanded pattern of life; to 'walk in it' means to live in obedience.

deliberation: Detected several idiomatic/metaphorical expressions: (1) 'did not incline their ear' for refusing to heed, (2) 'walked in the counsels and stubbornness of their evil heart' continuing path imagery, and (3) 'they became backward and not forward' as an orientation metaphor for moral regression.

instances.english_text: they did not give ear (they did not incline their ear)
target: The people’s refusal to pay attention to God’s messages
vehicle: Physically turning or inclining an ear toward a sound
ground: Inclining the ear toward a speaker symbolizes readiness to listen; refusing to do so represents willful inattention
bodily posture as sign of inner stance
instances.explanation: The idiom 'incline the ear' uses bodily imagery to depict attentive listening; its negation pictures willful refusal to heed.

instances.english_text: they followed their own counsels, the willfulness of their evil hearts
vehicle: Walking along within counsels and stubbornness as if along a path
ground: Living according to one’s inner plans is likened to walking a path laid out by the heart’s stubborn advice
instances.explanation: The verse extends path imagery inward: they 'walk' in the counsels of their evil heart, depicting their lives as guided by stubborn inner pathways.

instances.english_text: They have gone backward, not forward
target: moral and religious progress or decline
vehicle: A person moving backward instead of forward
ground: Moral/spiritual decline is pictured as moving in reverse rather than advancing
progress vs. regression mapped onto front/back motion
posture: Strong negative assessment of their history
instances.explanation: The orientation metaphor equates moral decline with walking backward instead of progressing forward.

deliberation: The time-span 'from the day your ancestors left Egypt until this day' is chronological rather than figurative. The notable idiom is again 'rising early and sending' the prophets, which anthropomorphically portrays God’s diligence.

instances.english_text: daily and persistently (rising early and sending)
target: frequency and zeal of His sending
vehicle: A person who gets up early each day to send out messengers
ground: Both an early-rising sender and God’s activity show persistent initiative over time
posture: Self-justification of God’s patience vs. their stubbornness
instances.explanation: The idiom 'rising early and sending' again personifies God as an eager human dispatcher to highlight His persistent sending of prophets.

deliberation: Considered 'would not listen' as literal refusal, and found a clear metaphor in 'they stiffened their neck' (הִקְשׁוּ אֶת־עׇרְפָּם), drawn from stubborn animals resisting the yoke.

instances.english_text: They stiffened their necks
target: The people’s obstinate refusal to submit to God
vehicle: An animal that hardens its neck and resists a yoke
ground: Both a stiff-necked animal and Israel resist guidance and refuse to bend to the yoke
instances.explanation: The 'stiff neck' metaphor likens Israel to an animal that refuses the yoke, emphasizing their refusal to submit.

deliberation: Straightforward prediction that they will not listen or answer Jeremiah. 'Speak' and 'call' are literal communicative verbs; no distinctive figurative imagery is exploited here.

Observed two figures: (1) 'did not listen to the voice of YHWH' where 'voice' is metonymic for command and 'listen' idiomatic for obey; (2) 'Faithfulness has perished, and is cut off from their mouths' personifies faithfulness as a living entity that can die and be excised from speech.

instances.hebrew_text: הַגּוֹי אֲשֶׁר לֹא־שָׁמְעוּ בְּקוֹל יְהוָה אֱלֹהָיו
instances.english_text: This is the nation that would not obey the voice of the LORD their God
target: Their refusal to obey God’s commands
vehicle: A 'voice' that one can listen to or ignore
ground: God’s commands are conceptualized as His 'voice,' and to 'listen' to it is to obey
instances.explanation: God’s 'voice' stands metonymically for His commands, and 'listening to the voice' is an idiom for obedient response.

instances.english_text: Faithfulness has perished, vanished from their mouths
vehicle: A living entity that can die ('perish') and be cut off from the mouth
ground: Faithfulness is treated like a living presence once in their speech that has now died and been excised
absence of a virtue pictured as death and removal
loss manifested in what they no longer say
instances.explanation: Abstract 'faithfulness' is personified as something that can perish and be cut off from their mouths, highlighting its complete disappearance from their speech.

deliberation: The imperatives are in feminine singular, addressing Jerusalem/Zion as a woman commanded to shear her 'nazir' locks and lament on the heights. This is a personification of the city/people as a mourning woman performing symbolic acts of grief.

instances.hebrew_text: גׇּזִּי נִזְרֵךְ וְהַשְׁלִיכִי וּשְׂאִי עַל־שְׁפָיִם קִינָה
instances.english_text: Shear your locks and cast them away, Take up a lament on the heights
target: Jerusalem/Zion and its inhabitants under judgment
vehicle: A woman (possibly a Nazirite-like figure) shaving her hair and wailing publicly on high places
ground: The city’s rejection and sorrow are expressed by picturing her as a woman performing traditional mourning gestures
external signs (shorn hair, lament) embody inward and communal grief
posture: Command to embody and acknowledge judgment
instances.explanation: Jerusalem is personified as a woman told to cut off her consecrated hair and wail on the heights, dramatizing her rejection and grief.

deliberation: Most elements (abominations placed in the house, defiling it) are literal cultic language. 'The house that is called by My name' again uses 'name' metonymically for divine presence.

instances.english_text: in the House that is called by My name
target: The temple as sanctified dwelling of God
vehicle: A building marked with an owner’s name
ground: The owner’s name on a house signifies belonging; God’s name on the temple signifies His claim and presence there
posture: Intensifying the seriousness of their defilement
instances.explanation: God’s 'name' again stands metonymically for His person; the house called by His name is the temple He claims as His own.

deliberation: The horrific actions (building Topheth, burning sons and daughters) are literal. The clause 'which I never commanded, which never came to My mind/heart' uses the idiom 'come up upon the heart' for conceiving an idea, an anthropomorphic idiom for divine thought.

instances.english_text: which never came to My mind (did not rise upon My heart)
target: God’s will and conceptualization regarding child sacrifice
vehicle: An idea rising up onto a human heart
movement of a thought toward the inner self
spatial ascent into the seat of thinking
ground: Conceiving an idea is pictured as something rising into one’s heart; saying it never rose emphasizes total foreignness to God’s will
inner cognition portrayed as spatial motion
non-occurrence expressed as absence of that motion
instances.explanation: The idiom 'did not come up upon My heart' anthropomorphically depicts God’s thought process; the figure denies that child sacrifice ever even entered His mind.

deliberation: Observed the renaming of Topheth/Valley of Ben-Hinnom as 'Valley of Slaughter.' This new toponym functions metaphorically, branding the place by the coming massacre that will characterize it.

instances.english_text: but [it will be called] the Valley of Slaughter
target: The future state and reputation of the valley
its role as site of mass death
vehicle: A valley identified by the abstract noun 'slaughter'
ground: Naming the valley 'Slaughter' depicts its defining characteristic as widespread killing, so that the place and the massacre are inseparably linked
metonymic fusion of location and fate
posture: Prophetic branding of the site as cursed
instances.explanation: The new name 'Valley of Slaughter' is a metaphorical/toponymic label where the event of slaughter stands for and defines the place.

deliberation: The gruesome image of carcasses as food for birds and beasts is a standard covenant-curse motif but is literal in content; it does not rely on metaphor or personification beyond the shocking description itself.

Identified 'I will silence… the sound of mirth and gladness, the voice of bridegroom and bride' as metonymic/merismic: the 'voice' of celebrations and weddings stands for the events and the entire fabric of joyous communal life that will cease.

instances.hebrew_text: ק֣וֹל שָׂשׂוֹן וְק֣וֹל שִׂמְחָה ק֥וֹל חָתָן וְק֣וֹל כַּלָּה
instances.english_text: the sound of mirth and gladness, the voice of bridegroom and bride
target: All joyful social life, especially celebrations and weddings in Judah
vehicle: Audible sounds and voices associated with joy and marriage ceremonies
sounds of feasting and wedding voices
ground: The sounds of joy and wedding voices represent the existence of community celebrations; silencing them signifies the end of social joy
posture: Announcement of total desolation of communal life
instances.explanation: The 'voice' of joy and of bridegroom/bride functions metonymically and as a merism for all occasions of communal happiness, whose cessation marks the land’s devastation.
